name: BBCWorld
text:
How exposed to coronavirus might you be in your job?

How does that compare to others?

See how your job ranks, using our tool

[Thread]

https://t.co/JXrPpFsG1j https://t.co/umWj1UwKEK

name: BBCWorld
text:
Most jobs require people to work relatively closely to others - that’s somewhere in the range between arm's length and a shared office environment 

There are actually very few that typically involve exposure to disease more than once a year

https://t.co/JXrPpFsG1j https://t.co/nVfnaozLjT

name: BBCWorld
text:
Almost all the jobs that have a high exposure to both disease and other people are healthcare professions

Cleaners, prison officers and undertakers are among those who have relatively high exposure without so much close interaction with other people

https://t.co/JXrPpFsG1j https://t.co/k2ax7AujZ7

name: BBCWorld
text:
But, the people who might be most at risk are those who have lots of close contact with people, but aren't used to being exposed to disease

Bar staff, hairdressers and actors fall into this category, as well as taxi drivers 

https://t.co/JXrPpFsG1j https://t.co/zXsnZmd6hc

name: BBCWorld
text:
Some jobs may find it easier to adjust than others
 
There may be slightly different working practices and conditions in some countries for certain occupations, but results are broadly the same in most developed countries

https://t.co/JXrPpFsG1j https://t.co/kUWgg45ZOT

name: BBCWorld
text:
How have you worked this out?

Data in the look-up comes from the UK’s Office for National Statistics

Figures on proximity to others and exposure to disease come from a survey by the US’ Occupational Information Network

Read about the methodology & more: https://t.co/JXrPpFsG1j
